survive.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to continue to live after an accident, war, or illness
survive.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to continue to live normally in spite of many problems
survive.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: I’m sure she will survive this crisis.
I’ve had a tough few months, but I’ll survive.
survive.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to manage to live a normal life even though you have very little money
survive.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: the amount that a family needs each week just to survive
I don’t know how you all manage to survive on Jeremy’s salary.
survive.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to continue to exist after a long time
survive.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: A few pages of the original manuscript still survive.
Several buildings in the town have survived from medieval times.
an old custom which has survived into the twenty-first century
The main building was demolished, but the library still survives as a museum.
survive.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: The car industry cannot survive without government help.
A lot of smaller firms did not survive the recession.
survive.translation[0].definitions[5].de: to live longer than someone else, usually someone closely related to you
survive.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: He is survived by his wife Sue.
survive.translation[1].definitions[0].de: if a business survives, it manages to continue operating, even though it is in a very difficult situation
survive.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: To survive, companies will have to focus on staff development.
The retailing company is cutting the number of its stores in an effort tosurvive its severe recessionaryproblems.
survive.translation[1].definitions[1].de: if you survive, you continue to live. If you survive someone, you continue to live after they have died
survive.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: Provided her husband survived her by 30 days, he would receive the income from her father’s estate.
